title: Amnon and Tamar
shortSummary: This chapter recounts the tragic story of Amnon's lust for his half-sister Tamar, his deceitful scheme to assault her, and the resulting family strife. It highlights the devastating consequences of sin within David's household and sets the stage for further conflict involving Absalom. The narrative underscores themes of lust, justice, and the fallout of unchecked evil.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - United Monarchy under King David

keyCharacters.name: Amnon
keyCharacters.description: Son of King David who lusts after and ultimately assaults his half-sister Tamar, triggering family tragedy.

keyCharacters.name: Tamar
keyCharacters.description: David’s daughter, sister to Absalom and Amnon, who becomes the victim of Amnon’s assault.

keyCharacters.name: Absalom
keyCharacters.description: David’s son and Tamar’s full brother who avenges her by killing Amnon and then flees.

keyCharacters.name: Jonadab
keyCharacters.description: Son of Shimeah, David’s brother, and a cunning friend who advises Amnon in his deceitful plan.

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: King of Israel and father to Amnon, Tamar, and Absalom, who reacts with anger but fails to administer immediate justice.

definitions.definition: A young woman who has not engaged in sexual relations, highly valued in ancient Israelite culture for purity and marriage.
A richly colored robe signifying royal status, often worn by king’s daughters who were virgins.
Workers who shear sheep’s wool; a social occasion often accompanied by feasting and gatherings.
Cunning or crafty, often implying shrewdness used for deceit or manipulation.

outline.heading: Amnon’s Lust and Deception
outline.description: Amnon becomes infatuated with Tamar and, following Jonadab’s advice, feigns illness to lure her into his chamber where he forcibly assaults her. This section reveals the destructive power of unchecked lust and deception.

outline.heading: Tamar’s Rejection and Desolation
outline.description: After the assault, Amnon’s love turns to hatred and he cruelly sends Tamar away. Tamar mourns deeply, and Absalom consoles her but harbors hatred for Amnon, setting up future vengeance.

outline.heading: David’s Reaction and Absalom’s Silence
outline.description: King David is angry upon hearing the news but takes no immediate action. Absalom distances himself from Amnon, nursing his hatred in silence.

outline.heading: Absalom’s Revenge
outline.description: Two years later, Absalom orchestrates a plan during a sheep-shearing feast to kill Amnon. His servants carry out the murder, and the king’s sons flee in fear.

outline.heading: Aftermath and Absalom’s Exile
outline.description: David mourns deeply, initially believing all his sons are dead. Jonadab clarifies only Amnon is dead. Absalom flees to Geshur and remains there for three years, while David longs for his return.

application: Guard your heart and mind against lustful desires, recognizing how they can lead to destructive actions and harm to others.
Seek God’s justice and righteousness rather than taking matters into your own hands or harboring hatred.
Respond to sin and wrongdoing with godly wisdom and courage, avoiding passivity in the face of evil.
Comfort and support those who have been wronged, just as Absalom initially consoles Tamar, but also pursue reconciliation and healing under God’s guidance.

keyVerses.text: Howbeit he would not hearken unto her voice: but, being stronger than she, forced her, and lay with her.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the tragic moment of Tamar’s assault, highlighting the grave sin of Amnon and the abuse of power.

keyVerses.text: But when king David heard of all these things, he was very wroth.
keyVerses.significance: David’s anger shows his recognition of the evil committed, though his lack of immediate action reveals complexities in leadership and justice.

keyVerses.text: And the servants of Absalom did unto Amnon as Absalom had commanded. Then all the king's sons arose, and every man gat him up upon his mule, and fled.
keyVerses.significance: This verse records Absalom’s violent revenge, illustrating the escalating consequences of sin within David’s family.

keyVerses.text: And the soul of king David longed to go forth unto Absalom: for he was comforted concerning Amnon, seeing he was dead.
keyVerses.significance: David’s longing for Absalom despite the turmoil shows the complexity of parental love and forgiveness amid family brokenness.
